Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Ontogenetic development of postcranial adaptations to bipedalism in the rat

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The evolution of bipedalism in hominins marks the origins of our lineage and represents a significant shift in locomotor pattern and musculoskeletal morphology. The evolutionary mechanisms that underpin this locomotor shift are unclear, however, with competing models suggesting differing selective pressures were responsible for the generation of bipedal traits. Research by doctoral student Adam Foster (University of Arizona), under the supervision of Dr. David Raichlen, will identify patterns in how morphology responds to behavior, contributing to our understanding of bipedal evolution.

The study directly tests for the roles that the amount and direction of mechanical loads (a shift from quadrupedal to bipedal standing and locomotion) have in generating adaptive morphology in the postcranial skeleton during ontogeny and adulthood, using a rat model. The research explores three main questions: (1) what role do bipedal standing and/or bipedal walking have in generating adaptive changes in skeletal morphology, (2) what is the role of ontogeny (i.e., developmental plasticity) in the generation of adaptive bipedal morphology, and (3) do morphological changes associated with locomotor shifts during ontogeny impact kinematics and energetics? Rats will be placed in a custom harness system mounted over a treadmill that allows for comfortable bipedal locomotion or static loading when the belt is not in motion, and will exercise or stand for one hour a day, 5 days a week, for 90 days. Skeletal changes are tracked through micro-CT scans, and kinematics and energetics data examine potential energy cost reductions associated with morphological changes. The findings will contribute to identifying how behavior drives morphological adaptation, and which morphologies may have been the first to evolve in response to a change in locomotion in the earliest hominins.

The study enhances research opportunities for undergraduates by directly involving them in data collection and analysis, and involves outreach to the community. Results from this study will be used to develop an evolution lab at a local high school; the lab and scan results will become a permanent resource for students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this study, a novel method was used to experimentally induce a locomotor shift during ontogeny in an animal model for the quadrupedal-to-bipedal transition to examine the role of developmental plasticity in generating adaptive traits. Rats were placed in a custom harness system mounted on a treadmill which allowed for bipedal locomotion or upright standing over 60 minute periods, 5 days a week, for three months. The harness imparts an adjustable upward force on the torso which alters the load experienced by the hindlimbs. To tease apart the independent effects of posture and locomotion, rats were divided into three model groups: a bipedal exercise group, a bipedal posture group (standing with no exercise), and a partially loaded bipedal group (rats walked bipedally, but, using a harness system that imparts an upward force on the torso, rats experienced a change the direction of load, but not the amount of load normally experienced by the hindlimb). These groups were compared to a control group of rats that are exercised quadrupedally, and a control group that did not exercise, resulting in five experimental groups (n=14/group). Skeletal changes were monitored via in vivo μCT scans every third week.  Energetic data were also collected at the end of the experiment to test whether morphological adaptations can be tied to reductions in energy costs of locomotion.

 

Below we list the specific hypotheses and results from the funded study.

 

1)      OBJECTIVE 1: The role of standing vs. exercise. A shift in either the direction and amount of load (fully loaded bipeds), the direction but not the amount (partially loaded bipeds), or static rather than dynamic loads (standing postural group) will generate morphology consistent with adaptation to bipedalism.

 

We measured long bone lengths and joint dimensions in all groups prior to the start of daily exercise and every third week following until the end of the experiment at Week 12. Here we show results from the final scan using a metric that takes into account the change in size relative to Week 0 ((Week 12 – Week0)/Week0). This approach offers a size corrected metric to compare across individuals. A one-way ANOVA demonstrated a significant interaction among experimental groups and relative limb length (femur + tibia) (F[4,65] = 3.9, p = 0.0067). Using a Fisher’s LSD post-hoc test to account for multiple comparisons, we found that relative limb length in the bipedal groups are significantly larger than in the quadrupedal and no activity controls (Table1; Figure 1). These results suggest that a locomotor and/or postural shift can generate changes in long bone length, but cannot tease apart the independent effects of direction, amount of load, or the role of static or dynamic forces.

 

Joint dimensions were compared using the same size corrected method ((Week 12 – Week 0)/Week 0) using a repeated measures MANOVA to reduce type I error associated with large numbers of pair-wise comparisons. The results indicated that group centroids were significantly different and warranted individual pair-wise comparisons to determine which variables differed between groups. A follow up Fisher’s LSD post-hoc test found differences in joint dimensions in the proximal femur (i.e., surface area of the femoral head) and the A-P dimension of the distal femur (Tables 2, 3).
